description: Early Philadelphia city record documenting the Pine Street neighborhood development near Rittenhouse Square.
John McCrea sells the newly completed townhouse at 1822 Pine Street to John Roset, merchant of French heritage. This deed marks the beginning of 170 years of documented ownership.
Philadelphia Inquirer coverage of Rittenhouse Square society and the prominent families residing on Pine Street.
Evening Telegraph reports on social gatherings and events in the Rittenhouse Square neighborhood.
News coverage of residential developments and society events along Pine Street near Rittenhouse Square.
Philadelphia Inquirer documents the growing prominence of Rittenhouse Square as Philadelphia's premier residential district.
Society news featuring the distinguished families of Pine Street and their winter social calendar.
High society tea hosted at a Rittenhouse Square residence, documenting the elegant entertaining traditions of the era.
Philadelphia Times coverage of winter social season events in the Rittenhouse Square neighborhood.
The Spencer family era begins at 1822 Pine Street, ushering in a new chapter of distinguished ownership.
Philadelphia Times features the Spencer family's social engagements and their prominence in Rittenhouse society.
Historic property sale: 1822 Pine Street transfers ownership for $14,000, reflecting its status as one of Philadelphia's finest addresses.
Deed abstract documents the transfer from the Roset estate trustee to Howard Spencer, beginning the Spencer family's ownership.
Philadelphia Times reports on changes in Rittenhouse Square property ownership and the neighborhood's continued prestige.
Front page coverage in the Philadelphia Inquirer documenting significant real estate activity in the Rittenhouse district.
Summer society news featuring the Spencer family and their activities in Philadelphia's social scene.
Autumn social calendar coverage including events hosted by prominent Pine Street families.
Agnes M. Spencer takes title to 1822 Pine Street, preparing the house for its turn-of-century transformation.
Philadelphia Inquirer reports on spring social season and architectural improvements in Rittenhouse Square homes.
Major architectural renovation announced: Duhring, Okie & Ziegler commissioned to modernize 1822 Pine Street while preserving its historic character.
Philadelphia Times documents the architectural transformation underway at 1822 Pine Street by renowned architects.
Turn of the century coverage of Rittenhouse Square's evolution into Philadelphia's most prestigious residential enclave.
Mrs. Graham Spencer returns to 1822 Pine Street for the winter season from her Chester County country estate.
Philadelphia Inquirer covers autumn gatherings and the continued social prominence of the Spencer residence.
Rolin-Plumb wedding breakfast served at 1822 Pine Street, highlighting the residence's role in Philadelphia society celebrations.
Mrs. Henry C. Davis and the Misses Davis host 'At Home' days at 1822 Pine Street during the winter social season.
J.N. Long installs the signature fireplace at 1822 Pine Street for $130â€”a centerpiece that continues to warm gatherings today.
Year-end social coverage documenting the continued prominence of 1822 Pine Street in Philadelphia society.
Holiday entertaining at the Spencer residence featured in Philadelphia Inquirer society pages.
New Year's social events and gatherings documented at prominent Rittenhouse Square addresses.
Philadelphia Inquirer coverage of women's activism growing in the Rittenhouse Square community.
Suffrage movement gains momentum with meetings held in Rittenhouse Square homes, including 1822 Pine Street.
Women's suffrage organizing continues in the parlors of prominent Philadelphia homes near Rittenhouse Square.
Suffragette strategy sessions and social activism documented in Rittenhouse neighborhood residences.
Miss Martha Davis of 1822 Pine Street sells Equal Franchise Society luncheon tickets, documenting suffrage activism at this address.
Deed abstract documenting property transfer as 1822 Pine Street transitions to professional and apartment use.
World War II era deed transfer documenting continued stewardship of the historic property.
Post-war deed abstract documenting property ownership as Rittenhouse Square adapts to changing times.
Mid-century deed transfer as the property continues its evolution through the apartment era.
Deed abstract recording ownership transition during the continued apartment conversion years.
Property deed transfer during the late 1960s as Rittenhouse Square undergoes urban renewal.
Deed transfer reflecting continued private ownership of 1822 Pine Street.
Property ownership transfer as 1822 Pine Street enters a new phase of stewardship.
Deed documentation as the property transitions toward historic preservation era.
1822 Pine Street receives historic protection as part of the Rittenhouse-Fitler Historic District, ensuring preservation of its architectural heritage.
Early 21st century deed transfer continuing the stewardship of this historic Rittenhouse Square property.
Current ownership establishes 1822 Pine Street as the Rittenhouse Residence, beginning its new chapter as a premier historic vacation rental for discerning guests.
